scientificExplanation: Discipline isn't willpower—it's trained through progressive voluntary discomfort. Research from Dr. Roy Baumeister shows self-control is like muscle: strengthens with use, weakens with overuse. Trying to build discipline through massive changes (cold turkey diets, 2-hour daily workouts) depletes willpower faster than it builds. Your prefrontal cortex (impulse control) requires 66+ days of consistent practice to automate new behaviors. Discipline = accumulated micro-wins creating identity shift ('I'm someone who follows through').
failedSolutions: New Year's resolutions with massive life overhauls (burn out by Jan 15)

Beating yourself up for lacking discipline (shame doesn't build skills)
Copying discipline routines from Navy SEALs/athletes (their baseline ≠ your baseline)

faqs.question: Is discipline genetic or can it really be learned?
faqs.answer: Discipline is 100% trainable skill, not genetic trait. Research shows self-control strengthens like muscle with progressive practice. People with 'natural discipline' simply trained it earlier (through sports, strict parenting, military, etc.). You're not behind—you're starting training now. NooLife's 66-day system builds discipline from scratch through progressive micro-challenges.

faqs.question: Why do I quit everything after 3-5 days?
faqs.answer: You're going too hard too fast. Trying to do 2-hour workouts when baseline is zero depletes willpower faster than it builds discipline. NooLife starts impossibly easy (5-min meditation, 10 pushups). Progressive difficulty as you adapt. You quit because your approach was unsustainable. Discipline builds gradually, not overnight.
